Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Study of giant magnetoresistance and induced electromotive force in GaMnAs-based magnetic tunnel junctions

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the past decade a significant new direction in materials research has emerged (referred to as “spintronics”), focused on developing devices that make use not only of the charge of charge carriers, but also of a quantum-mechanical property called spin for information storage and processing. To develop this new line of applications, suitable materials whose spin properties can be harnessed for such spin-based device purposes must first be fabricated. A giant step in that direction has been achieved by the discovery of ferromagnetism in certain semiconductor systems. Gallium Manganese Arsenide (GaMnAs) is a promising example, and a sizeable literature has already found focus on the properties of this ferromagnetic semiconductor.

The focus of this study on a spin-dependent electron transport effect called tunneling magnetoresistance (TMR) in GaMnAs-based heterostructures fabricated into magnetic tunnel junctions (MTJ). These MTJs are comprised of two ferromagnetic GaMnAs layers sandwiching a thin insulating barrier, or spacer layer. Classically, an electron would not be able to pass through the barrier, but quantum mechanics allows this. The two GaMnAs layers tune the resistance of the tunnel junction by direction of their magnetizations. If the magnetizations are parallel, the resistance will be less than if the magnetizations of the two layer are antiparallel, that is pointing in opposite directions. TMR is a measure of the difference in resistance across the MTJ between the parallel case and the antiparallel case. We study this effect by placing the samples in a magnetic field and measuring the resistance through the tunnel junctions. These magnetotransport studies were undertaken in the laboratory of Prof. Sanghoon Lee at the University of Korea in Seoul, South Korea in collaboration with the research of Prof. Jacek Furdyna and Prof. Malgorzata Dobrowolska at the University of Notre Dame in Notre Dame, IN.

The samples studied had spacer layers of GaAs and AlGaAs doped with Be. Previous studies have shown undoped GaAs and AlGaAs to be effective spacer layers leading to high TMR. Earlier work by Prof. Lee had shown that a GaMnAs/GaAs:Be/GaMnAs trilayers can demonstrate an effect called antiferromagnetic (AFM) coupling, where the two ferromagnetic GaMnAs layers naturally point in opposite directions. We sought to investigate the transport behavior of like-structure with current out-of-the-plane of the sample to examine any overlap in AFM coupling and TMR behaviors. What we found was that the resistance was greatly suppressed due to doping the spacer layer with Be, which inserts carriers into what is supposed to be an insulating spacer layer. Despite this, evidence of TMR was observable in a sample with high aluminum content in the spacer layer, indicating that the high enough barrier height of high-Al-concentration AlGaAs allows enough insulation to observe modest TMR effect.

The outcomes of my research, which included temperature dependent, field-dependent, and angle of applied field-dependent measurements, were presented at the APS annual March Meeting in Dallas, TX. In order to continue this research, we must find a spacer layer that, like GaAs:Be, carrier mediates AFM coupling in the two ferromagnetic layers, but remains an insulator. As I research this matter further, I have also begun to apply my developed skill with magnetotransport characterization towards investigating an exciting new material with newly realized quantum states called “topological insulators.”
